As you may know, there are 2 main approaches for this design:
1. The first has some distributed complexity in all the operations and an O(1) getNewsFeed.
2. The second is the O(1) for all operations and most of the complexity is the getNewsFeed.

**Which is better and why?**

I beleive that this is not an algorithmic/design problem this is a UX problem. Regardless of the actual complexities. Let's say that we have 2 users the first has 1M followers (people following him/her), let's call this user **celebrity** and the second user is following 1M other users and let's call this user **normal**.

* **Design 1 => The O(1) getNewsFeed.**
While both of the users will have a very fast and nice getNewsFeed experience let's think about posting a tweet.
  * The **celerity** will have a bad experience whenever he is posting a tweet and that's because he/she has a lot of followers and his new tweet will need somehow to be published to all the news feeds of the 1M followers.
  * The **normal** user will post a tweet in almost no time because he has very few or no followers.

* **Design 2 => The Complex getNewsFeed.**
This time both of the users will enjoy a fantastic O(1) post tweet, but then when it comes to getting the news feed.
  * The **celebrity** will is following few others and aggregating his/her news feed won't take long.
  * Although the **normal** user who is following 1M users will need sometime to aggregate his very complex news feed.

Now, if you took a closer look at the previous comparison you will find that the user who has taken explicit actions to follow lots and lots of people is making his/her feed complex, he/she unfollows people it becomse simpler. Although the celebrity who is not following a lot is getting better experience because he/she has not taken explicit actions to make other people follow him.

In other words, the first design is somehow punishing the celebrities for getting more and more followers while the second design is punishing the users who follow a lot of people.

***Which punishment would you choose for your users? :) :)***

I would argue that option two is far superior. I would suspect that number of followed users stays fairly constant and small among all users. The only way I can even imagine a user following a million users if if following can be performed programmatically via API. No one is pressing a subscribe button a million times.
O(n) getNewsFeed() then caching it

That was a great read , though the only one\'s which will get punished are us !\njokes aside ... I think it would be better to chose 2nd option , because the number of people a user follows is pretty limited , when we think about the majority of people... I have never seen someone follow more than a couple of thousand people , that too in rare case ( the accounts that want to grow , they deliberately follow people in hope of getting a follow back ).

Damn I feel like all interview questions should be like that. I loved this problem because:
- It is an object oriented design question which is already much closer to what you might actually do in a job than 99% problems 
- there are so many ways to approach it ! I've coded 3 different solutions to it which all have different perks and downsides (some of them put all the complexity in the post operation, some of them in the getnewsfeed, etc...). 
- It lets you use a variety of different data structures (I've used linked list, queue, heap, and I'm sure you could come up with other ways)
- it actually feels like a relevant problem that you're farely likely to encounter some variation of when coding real solutions. Not like a goddamn palindrome thing. Why, oh, why are problem makers fetishizing palindromes so much?

`[[],[1,5],[1,3],[1,101],[1,13],[1,10],[1,2],[1,94],[1,505],[1,333],[1,22],[1,11],[1]]`

It is because the latest 10 tweets should be returned

I find that this testcase should not be valid because in my opinion if a tweet is posted after another tweet, its id should be higher.
Here we have a tweet with id 5, and then id 3
And I based myself on this principle to solve the problem and for me these cases should not happen :c
Suppose user 1 doesn\'t follow anybody. User 2 posts 10 tweets in a row. THEN user 1 starts following user 2.\nAre the 10 posts supposed to show up on user 1\'s feed?
Thought this was fairly straightforward until submitting made me realize that feeds should include tweets from even before a user followed another user...\n
Is Elon going to hire me if I solve this question?)

I think there is a problem with test case no. 11.
This is their input:
`["Twitter","postTweet","postTweet","postTweet","postTweet","postTweet","postTweet","postTweet","postTweet","postTweet","postTweet","postTweet","getNewsFeed"]`
`[[],[1,5],[1,3],[1,101],[1,13],[1,10],[1,2],[1,94],[1,505],[1,333],[1,22],[1,11],[1]]`
However, their expected output is this:
`[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[11,22,333,505,94,2,10,13,101,3]]`
Why isn't `5` amongst the output? It was clearly posted at the very beginning. The first call `postTweet(1,5)` should have added it to the list of tweets. Therefore, it should be returned.
Anyone else having this issue?
It is because the latest 10 tweets should be returned

Code to generate test cases:

```
max_user_id = 5
ops_count = 100
ops = ["Twitter"]
args = [[]]
tweetId = 0

for i in range(ops_count):
    op = random.choice(["getNewsFeed", "follow", "unfollow", "postTweet"])
    ops.append(op)

for i in range(1, ops_count+1):
    op = ops[i]
    if op == "getNewsFeed":
        args.append([random.randint(1, max_user_id)])
    elif op == "follow" or op == "unfollow":
        follower_id = random.randint(1, max_user_id)
        unfollower_id = follower_id
        while unfollower_id == follower_id:
            unfollower_id = random.randint(1, max_user_id)
        args.append([follower_id, unfollower_id])
    elif op == "postTweet":
        args.append([random.randint(1, max_user_id), tweetId])
        tweetId += 1
print(json.dumps(ops))
print(json.dumps(args))
```

        args.append([follower_id, unfollower_id])
    elif op == "postTweet":
        args.append([random.randint(1, max_user_id), tweetId])
        tweetId += 1
print(json.dumps(ops))
print(json.dumps(args))
```

title: Assign Cookies
question_content:
Assume you are an awesome parent and want to give your children some cookies. But, you should give each child at most one cookie.

Each child i has a greed factor g[i], which is the minimum size of a cookie that the child will be content with; and each cookie j has a size s[j]. If s[j] >= g[i], we can assign the cookie j to the child i, and the child i will be content. Your goal is to maximize the number of your content children and output the maximum number.

 

Example 1:

Input: g = [1,2,3], s = [1,1]
Output: 1
Explanation: You have 3 children and 2 cookies. The greed factors of 3 children are 1, 2, 3. 
And even though you have 2 cookies, since their size is both 1, you could only make the child whose greed factor is 1 content.
You need to output 1.

Example 2:

Input: g = [1,2], s = [1,2,3]
Output: 2
Explanation: You have 2 children and 3 cookies. The greed factors of 2 children are 1, 2. 
You have 3 cookies and their sizes are big enough to gratify all of the children, 
You need to output 2.

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= g.length <= 3 * 104
  • 0 <= s.length <= 3 * 104
  • 1 <= g[i], s[j] <= 231 - 1

solutions.title: simple-greedy-java-solution
simple-python-o-nlogn
solutions.content:
```
class Solution(object):
    def findContentChildren(self, g, s):
        """
        :type g: List[int]
        :type s: List[int]
        :rtype: int
        """
        g.sort()
        s.sort()
        
        childi = 0
        cookiei = 0
        
        while cookiei < len(s) and childi < len(g):
            if s[cookiei] >= g[childi]:
                childi += 1
            cookiei += 1
        
        return childi
                
```

solutions.title: easy-understanding-c-solution-o-nlogn
python3
solutions.content:
```
# 先对g, s两个数组进行排序
# 贪心算法
# 贪心思想1 优先满足需求因子较小的孩子。因为如果较小需求的孩子无法被满足，则之后的较大的需求更不可能能被满足了。
#贪心思想2 尽量用较小的糖果去优先满足孩子。

class Solution:
    def findContentChildren(self, g, s):
        """
        :type g: List[int]
        :type s: List[int]
        :rtype: int
        """
        g.sort()    # 对需求因子进行排序，从小到大
        s.sort()    # 对糖果数组进行排序，从小到大
        child  = 0  # 记录可以被满足孩子数
        cookie = 0  # 记录可以满足的糖果数
        while  child <len(g) and cookie < len(s):
            if g[child] <= s[cookie]: 
                child += 1
            cookie += 1
        return child
```

#贪心思想2 尽量用较小的糖果去优先满足孩子。

class Solution:

                child += 1

```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:
        i, j, ans = 0, 0, 0
        g.sort()
        s.sort()
        while i < len(g) and j < len(s):
            if s[j] >= g[i]:
                ans, i = ans + 1, i + 1
            j += 1
        return ans
```

solutions.title: c-java-python-js-fully-explained-greedy-two-pointers-heap-priority-queue-sorting
455-solution-with-step-by-step-explanation
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
1. Define the findContentChildren function that takes in two lists of integers, g and s, and returns an integer representing the number of content children.
2. Sort the lists g and s in non-decreasing order using the sort() method.
3. Initialize two indices i and j to 0.
4. While i is less than the length of g and j is less than the length of s, do the following:
a. Check if the current cookie s[j] is large enough to satisfy the current child's greed g[i].
b. If the current cookie is large enough, increment i to indicate that the current child has been assigned a cookie.
c. Regardless of whether a cookie was assigned or not, increment j to move to the next cookie.
5. Return the value of i as the number of content children.
# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:
        g.sort()
        s.sort()
        i, j = 0, 0
        while i < len(g) and j < len(s):
            if s[j] >= g[i]:
                i += 1
            j += 1
        return i

```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:
        gs,ss = sorted(g),sorted(s)
        c = 0
        while ss and gs:
            if ss[-1] >= gs[-1]:
                ss.pop()
                c += 1
            gs.pop()
        return c
```

The logic:

1. First, we sort lists a prepare a counter `c`:

```
        gs,ss = sorted(g),sorted(s)
        c = 0
```

2. While we have something left in both lists we:

- Pick the largest candy:
- Keep skipping kids if their grid factor is larger than the current candy
- If we find a kid who would be happy with the current candy - take that candy out of the list and increase the counter
```
        while ss and gs:
            if ss[-1] >= gs[-1]:
                ss.pop()
                c += 1
            gs.pop()
```

3. Return the counter.

Ok, here is a tip. While some solutions use pointers, if you use `pop()`, that saves two pointers and allows us to get away with only 3 extra variables insted of 5.

def findContentChildren(self, g, s):

solutions.content:
# Intuition
Think like dad👨‍👦‍👦!
- You have a cookies & you first think how to give cookies to childrens :
- case1 : Random order
- case2 : Give minimum size cookie which child have minimum greed & then jump into another child (when first child satisfy).
- At the end you have maximum child feed.
# Approach
### case2
- Sort both g & s.
- Loop over cookie(s) & check it is satisy greed of child then increment child.
- return child.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
O(Nlog(N))  (sorting)
- Space complexity:
O(N) (sorting)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:

        # Sort g & s
        g.sort()
        s.sort()
        
        # Set child to zero
        child = 0
        
        # Loop over s(cookies)
        for cookie in s:
            
            # If child greed satisfy
            if cookie >= g[child]:
                
                # Then increment child
                child += 1
                
            # If no child left
            if child == len(g):
                
                # Then return child
                return child
        
        # Return child
        return child
```

solutions.content:
A greedy solution where we sort and greedy and size lists. Now loop through both the lists to greedily assign a greedy child a cookie based on the condition: s[j] >= g[i].


Time Complexity: O(nlogn) where n is max(g,s) sizes
```
class Solution:
    def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:
        
        #Sort Greed Factor and Cookie Size
        g.sort()
        s.sort()
        
        #Initialise ans
        ans = 0
        
        i = 0
        j = 0
        
        while(i<len(g) and j<len(s)):
            
            #Cookie Assigned
            if(s[j] >= g[i]):
                ans += 1
                j += 1
                i += 1
            #Search if any cookie will be enough for greed    
            else:
                j += 1
        return ans
```

def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:
        g.sort()
        s.sort()
        # the logic is to give the children the smallest size cookie available to satisfy their greed
        # since child list is sorted, the next child will obviously ask for size >= previous size allocated
        
        i,j = 0,0
        res = 0
        while i<len(g) and j < len(s):

            if g[i] <= s[j]:
                # if greed is less than size, then give the cookie and increment size and greed pointers
                i += 1
                j += 1
                res +=1
            else:
                # if greed is greater than size, we can't allocate so just increment the size pointer to see 
                # if next cookie size could satisfy the greed
                j+=1
				return res

```
def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:
        # TOPIC: s can random to send to children, s[any j] >= g[any i] as much as possible
        # HOW: sort children in decrease order and s cookies as well. since most content should match with most cookies
        
        if not g or not s or len(g) == 0 or len(s) == 0: return 0
    
        res = 0
        
        g.sort(reverse=True)
        s.sort(reverse=True)
        
        i = 0
        j = 0
        while i < len(g) and j < len(s):
            if s[j] < g[i]:
                # cannot meet content, cur child need higher content, so find next less content
                i+=1
            else:
                res += 1
                i+=1
                j+=1
                
        return res
        
```

solutions.content:
The algorithm is simple.

1. Sort the cookies and greed factor arrays
2. Since the input arrays are sorted, we can then have 2 pointers. One that keeps track of the current cookie we are looking at, and another keeps track of how many children were fed.
3. If a cookie is too small, then we need to move on to the next cookie, if it is good then we also need to move on to the next cookie. So we always move on to the next cookie.
4. If a cookie is too small, then we cannot shift the pointer that keeps track of how many children have been fed. If a cookie is the right size then we can move the pointer that keeps track of the child who was properly fed.

```
class Solution:
    def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:
        g.sort()
        s.sort()
        g_len = len(g)
        ans = 0
        for size in s:
            # If all of the cookies have been consumed, we can just return
            if ans >= g_len:
                return ans
            # If the cookie is acceptable, then a cookie is consumed and a child is satisfied
            if size >= g[ans]:
                ans += 1
        return ans
```

class Solution:
    def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:
        g.sort()  # O(nlogn)
        s.sort()  # O(nlogn)
        
        child_point = 0
        cookie_point = 0
        counter = 0
        
        # O(n)
        while child_point < len(g) and cookie_point < len(s):
            if g[child_point] <= s[cookie_point]:
                counter += 1
                child_point += 1
                cookie_point += 1
            else:
                cookie_point += 1
            
        return counter
        
```

    def findContentChildren(self, g, s):

        g.sort()

        s_length = len(s)

solutions.content:
**Solution**

**Assign Cookies** https://leetcode.com/problems/assign-cookies/

**Greedy Algorithm**
* Sort greed array and cookie array. Then simply walk both arrays and match cookie to greed if greed is less than cookie.
```
class Solution(object):
    def findContentChildren(self, g, s):
        """
        :type g: List[int]
        :type s: List[int]
        :rtype: int
        """
        g.sort()
        s.sort()
        i, j, cnt = 0,0,0
        while i < len(g) and j < len(s):
            if g[i] <= s[j]:
                cnt, i, j = cnt+1, i+1, j+1
            else:
                j += 1
        return cnt
```

solutions.title: python-solution-with-explanation-o-n-log-n
solutions.content:
My solution considers that in order to satisfy children with as many cookies as possible, we have to satisfy the greediest children first. The next children will be less greedy, and so our smaller cookies will have better use on them. If we can't satisfy a greedy child with our largest cookie, we skip the child and try to feed a less greedy one.

```
    def findContentChildren(self, g, s):

        # sort both beforehand
        g.sort()
        s.sort()
        
        # count the number of satisfied children
        satisfied_count = 0
        
        # match the largest cookies to the largest child they can satisfy (skip children if you can't satisfy them)
        largest_cookie = None
        for child_greed in reversed(g):
            
            # pop a cookie if we have one left, and aren't currently trying to feed a child with one
            if largest_cookie is None and len(s) > 0:
                largest_cookie = s.pop()
                
            # check if we can satisfy the current child with this cookie
            if child_greed <= largest_cookie:
                
                # if we fed the child, reset the cookie size so we can replace it with the next largest one next round
                satisfied_count += 1
                largest_cookie = None
        
        # return the total number of satisfied children
        return satisfied_count
```

The solution uses O(1) extra memory since the sorts are in place, and ```reversed(g)``` is an iterator over the original list, and the time complexity is O(n log n), where ```n = max( len(g), len(s) )```, due to the larger sort being the operation that grows at the fastest rate as input size increases.

solutions.content:
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
First we sort the array in ascending order. Then we take two pointers lets say greed pointer and cookie pointer.
We iterate over the cookie array and check if we foind a cookie that satisfies the greed of the child where out greed pointer is located, if yes the only we increment both greed pointer and cookie pointer and also the counter, if no we only increment the cookie pointer and check the condition again.
After the loop exits, we return the counter.

**If you like my solution please upvote. It motivates me a lot.**
**Happy Coding !!**
# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(nlog(n))
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(1)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
function findContentChildren(g: number[], s: number[]): number {
    let gpointer = 0
    let spointer = 0
    let counter = 0
    g.sort((a,b) => {return (a-b)})
    s.sort((a,b) => {return (a-b)})
    while(gpointer < g.length && spointer < s.length){
        if(s[spointer] >= g[gpointer]){
            counter ++
            gpointer ++
        }

        spointer ++
    }

    return counter
};
```

solutions.content:
```python
class Solution:
    def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:
        g.sort() # soring list g
        s.sort() # sorting list s
        # because it`ll make easy for us to figure out how many children are getting the cookies as per greedy.
        
        childi = 0 # taking variable
        cookiei = 0 # taking variable
        
        while cookiei < len(s) and childi < len(g): # traversing elements in the list. 
            if s[cookiei] >= g[childi]: # checking if cookies are more or equal to a child greedy.
                childi += 1 # if child greedy is getting fulfilled it will be content, and will increase out counter.
            cookiei += 1 # if child is getting the cookie, then we are increasing both else we`ll just check in cookies could we have any to fulfill at least one child greedy for that will increase only cookie
        
        return childi # returning the number of content children.
        
```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:
        g.sort()
        s.sort()
        
        i = 0
        j = 0
        countCookie = 0
        while j < len(s) and i < len(g):
            if s[j] >= g[i]:
                countCookie += 1
                j += 1
                i += 1
            elif s[j] <= g[i]:
                j += 1         
        return countCookie
```

class Solution:
    def findContentChildren(self, g: List[int], s: List[int]) -> int:
        g.sort()
        s.sort()
        
        i = 0
        j = 0
        countCookie = 0
        while j < len(s) and i < len(g):
            if s[j] >= g[i]:
                countCookie += 1
                j += 1
                i += 1
            elif s[j] <= g[i]:
                j += 1         
        return countCookie
```

# so true. dont give 2 examples with perfectly ordered examples
What if each child can get more than 1 cookies? Still each cookie can only be assigned to 1 child.
This is poorly written, it should more directly state that you can only give each child 1 cookie. It is not clear what the restrictions are from the read me.

The Greedy algorithm is :
always give the person who has smallest requirement smallest cookies;

Obviously, the persons who get cookies in Greedy algorithm are in continuous ascending order by requirement and starting from the person who has smallest requirement.
Let A donates the optimal result set  sorted by requirement and size is n, then A can be converted into the set that contains the persons who are in continuous ascending order by requirement and starting from the person who has 
smallest requirement.
Let B donates the result set sorted by requirement gotten from Greedy algorithm and size is k.
Obviously,  k <= n. The Greedy algorithm is correct only if k == n.
Following is the proof for k == n.
I will use contradiction to demonstrate k can't be less than n.

lemma: Ai >= Bi, i is in {1 ... k}, this lemma can be gotten directly from Greedy Algorithm which is 
always giving the person who has smallest requirement smallest cookies;

By lemma, we can get Ak+1 >= Bk.
if Ak+1 > Bk, B1...Bk, Ak+1, ... An can form new optimal result, but this is the contradicted with the size only being k for the result gotten from Greedy Algorithm.
if Ak+1 == Bk, there must be An-1 == Bk. let's say the continuous same requirement person in B is from Bj ... Bk, so Aj...Ak also are same and Ak+1 ... An also same, it means Bj...Bk,Ak+1,...An still can form new optimal result, this is contracdicted with the size only is k for the result gotten from Greedy Algorithm.
So, k == n.
[@dhtmlkitchen](/dhtmlkitchen)  They meant "denotes". A lemma is "A thing we assume to be true for the purpose of this proof", its a maths term.

"Let B donates the result set sorted by requirement gotten from Greedy algorithm and size is k."

What? 

And what is lemma?
What if two children have same greed factor?
Then any one of them get cookies
The key point to solve this using two pointers is that cookies are to be greater than or equal to the children number inside the loops.
[@bparanj](/bparanj) Thank you very much, I understood from the example.

The provided code doesn't guarantee to satisfy the maximum number of children, because it doesn't always satisfy the child with the least "greed" factor first. Specifically, it loops over the cookies, then for each cookie, it loops over the children and assigns the cookie to the first child it encounters whose "greed" is less than or equal to the cookie size. The issue arises from the fact that a cookie could be given to a child with a higher "greed" factor, while a child with a lower "greed" factor could remain unsatisfied.

Consider an example:

- `g = [1, 2, 3]`, `s = [3, 1, 2]` - greed factors and cookie sizes are the same but not in the same order. 

With the existing code, here's how the distribution might look:

- Cookie of size 3 goes to child with greed 1.
- Cookie of size 1 goes to child with greed 2.
- Cookie of size 2 cannot satisfy any remaining child (with greed 3).

Although all children could be satisfied, only 2 children get cookies because of how the cookies are distributed.

Sorting both the greed factor and size arrays in increasing order ensures that each cookie goes to the child with the smallest possible "greed" factor that it can satisfy. In other words, each cookie goes to the "least greedy" child it can satisfy, thereby maximizing the number of satisfied children. This is why the code works when you sort the vectors.

In the sorted version of the example above:

- `g = [1, 2, 3]`, `s = [1, 2, 3]` (both sorted in increasing order).

The distribution now looks like:

- Cookie of size 1 goes to child with greed 1.
- Cookie of size 2 goes to child with greed 2.
- Cookie of size 3 goes to child with greed 3.

Now all children get cookies.

What if there is some cookies that will be wasted? For example if there are three children with a greed factors of 1,2,3 and cookie size of 1,3. Should a cookie be given to the child with a greed factor of 2 or greed factor of 3?
who the f*** have  3 * 10^4  children
Your comment is logical. The question statement could be better modified to replace \'parent\' with school headmaster or coach etc who has such a high number of children under his guidance.

Sorting both the greed factor and size arrays in increasing order ensures that each cookie goes to the child with the smallest possible "greed" factor that it can satisfy. In other words, each cookie goes to the "least greedy" child it can satisfy, thereby maximizing the number of satisfied children. This is why the code works when you sort the vectors.

In the sorted version of the example above:

- `g = [1, 2, 3]`, `s = [1, 2, 3]` (both sorted in increasing order).

The distribution now looks like:

- Cookie of size 1 goes to child with greed 1.
- Cookie of size 2 goes to child with greed 2.
- Cookie of size 3 goes to child with greed 3.

Now all children get cookies.

What if there is some cookies that will be wasted? For example if there are three children with a greed factors of 1,2,3 and cookie size of 1,3. Should a cookie be given to the child with a greed factor of 2 or greed factor of 3?

lemma: Ai >= Bi, i is in {1 ... k}, this lemma can be gotten directly from Greedy Algorithm which is

Let A donates the optimal result set  sorted by requirement and size is n, then A can be converted into the set that contains the persons who are in continuous ascending order by requirement and starting from the person who has 
smallest requirement.
Let B donates the result set sorted by requirement gotten from Greedy algorithm and size is k.
Obviously,  k <= n. The Greedy algorithm is correct only if k == n.
Following is the proof for k == n.
I will use contradiction to demonstrate k can't be less than n.

lemma: Ai >= Bi, i is in {1 ... k}, this lemma can be gotten directly from Greedy Algorithm which is 
always giving the person who has smallest requirement smallest cookies;

By lemma, we can get Ak+1 >= Bk.
if Ak+1 > Bk, B1...Bk, Ak+1, ... An can form new optimal result, but this is the contradicted with the size only being k for the result gotten from Greedy Algorithm.
if Ak+1 == Bk, there must be An-1 == Bk. let's say the continuous same requirement person in B is from Bj ... Bk, so Aj...Ak also are same and Ak+1 ... An also same, it means Bj...Bk,Ak+1,...An still can form new optimal result, this is contracdicted with the size only is k for the result gotten from Greedy Algorithm.
So, k == n.
[@dhtmlkitchen](/dhtmlkitchen)  They meant "denotes". A lemma is "A thing we assume to be true for the purpose of this proof", its a maths term.

"Let B donates the result set sorted by requirement gotten from Greedy algorithm and size is k."

What? 

And what is lemma?
What if two children have same greed factor?
Then any one of them get cookies
The key point to solve this using two pointers is that cookies are to be greater than or equal to the children number inside the loops.
[@bparanj](/bparanj) Thank you very much, I understood from the example.

The provided code doesn't guarantee to satisfy the maximum number of children, because it doesn't always satisfy the child with the least "greed" factor first. Specifically, it loops over the cookies, then for each cookie, it loops over the children and assigns the cookie to the first child it encounters whose "greed" is less than or equal to the cookie size. The issue arises from the fact that a cookie could be given to a child with a higher "greed" factor, while a child with a lower "greed" factor could remain unsatisfied.

Consider an example:

- `g = [1, 2, 3]`, `s = [3, 1, 2]` - greed factors and cookie sizes are the same but not in the same order. 

With the existing code, here's how the distribution might look:

- Cookie of size 3 goes to child with greed 1.
- Cookie of size 1 goes to child with greed 2.
- Cookie of size 2 cannot satisfy any remaining child (with greed 3).

Although all children could be satisfied, only 2 children get cookies because of how the cookies are distributed.

Sorting both the greed factor and size arrays in increasing order ensures that each cookie goes to the child with the smallest possible "greed" factor that it can satisfy. In other words, each cookie goes to the "least greedy" child it can satisfy, thereby maximizing the number of satisfied children. This is why the code works when you sort the vectors.

In the sorted version of the example above:

- `g = [1, 2, 3]`, `s = [1, 2, 3]` (both sorted in increasing order).

The distribution now looks like:

- Cookie of size 1 goes to child with greed 1.
- Cookie of size 2 goes to child with greed 2.
- Cookie of size 3 goes to child with greed 3.

Now all children get cookies.

What if there is some cookies that will be wasted? For example if there are three children with a greed factors of 1,2,3 and cookie size of 1,3. Should a cookie be given to the child with a greed factor of 2 or greed factor of 3?

Specifically, it loops over the cookies, then for each cookie, it loops over the children and assigns the cookie to the first child it encounters whose "greed" is less than or equal to the cookie size. The issue arises from the fact that a cookie could be given to a child with a higher "greed" factor, while a child with a lower "greed" factor could remain unsatisfied.

Consider an example:

- `g = [1, 2, 3]`, `s = [3, 1, 2]` - greed factors and cookie sizes are the same but not in the same order. 

With the existing code, here's how the distribution might look:

- Cookie of size 3 goes to child with greed 1.
- Cookie of size 1 goes to child with greed 2.
- Cookie of size 2 cannot satisfy any remaining child (with greed 3).

Although all children could be satisfied, only 2 children get cookies because of how the cookies are distributed.

Sorting both the greed factor and size arrays in increasing order ensures that each cookie goes to the child with the smallest possible "greed" factor that it can satisfy. In other words, each cookie goes to the "least greedy" child it can satisfy, thereby maximizing the number of satisfied children. This is why the code works when you sort the vectors.

In the sorted version of the example above:

- `g = [1, 2, 3]`, `s = [1, 2, 3]` (both sorted in increasing order).

The distribution now looks like:

- Cookie of size 1 goes to child with greed 1.
- Cookie of size 2 goes to child with greed 2.
- Cookie of size 3 goes to child with greed 3.

Now all children get cookies.

What if there is some cookies that will be wasted? For example if there are three children with a greed factors of 1,2,3 and cookie size of 1,3. Should a cookie be given to the child with a greed factor of 2 or greed factor of 3?

always give the person who has smallest requirement smallest cookies;

smallest requirement.
Let B donates the result set sorted by requirement gotten from Greedy algorithm and size is k.
Obviously,  k <= n. The Greedy algorithm is correct only if k == n.
Following is the proof for k == n.
I will use contradiction to demonstrate k can't be less than n.

lemma: Ai >= Bi, i is in {1 ... k}, this lemma can be gotten directly from Greedy Algorithm which is 
always giving the person who has smallest requirement smallest cookies;

By lemma, we can get Ak+1 >= Bk.
if Ak+1 > Bk, B1...Bk, Ak+1, ... An can form new optimal result, but this is the contradicted with the size only being k for the result gotten from Greedy Algorithm.
if Ak+1 == Bk, there must be An-1 == Bk. let's say the continuous same requirement person in B is from Bj ... Bk, so Aj...Ak also are same and Ak+1 ... An also same, it means Bj...Bk,Ak+1,...An still can form new optimal result, this is contracdicted with the size only is k for the result gotten from Greedy Algorithm.
So, k == n.

Can we Solve this problem with Dijkstra Shortest Path? I tried but only 198/226 Test case are passing.

What is maxJump for,  is the number of Jumps I have to take to reach last index, or its the range of my jump from any index i.

For Example
Input: coins = [1,2,4,-1,2], maxJump = 1
Output: []

Why output is empty, I can take 1 jump from each index and reach the last.
?
[@isakovi](/isakovi)  Thanks\n

You can't jump to an index with `-1` as its value

> You can jump to any index `i` of the array `coins` if `coins[i] != -1`

So index 3 (or 4 in the problem statement) has `-1` in it, therefore we cannot reach the last index
